Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MiSEP and
your contract.

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation

ALLEGATION:
On 8/24/22, youth assaulted staff. Staff attempted to restrain youth. During this
time, a staff member punch youth and pulled youth's hair. Youth was not injured but
did have pain.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Supervisor/Complainant was interviewed via phone on 9/1/22. Staff 2 was
interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 8/26/22. Staff 3 and Staff 5
were interviewed face to face separately on site at the facility on 9/1/22. All
interviews were conducted with the MDHHS Worker. Director was also present
for interviews with Supervisor, Staff 3 and Staff 5. On 8/24/22, Youth A told
Supervisor Staff 1 punched her and pulled her hair. Supervisor, Staff 2, Staff 3, and
Staff 5 reported Youth A pulled Staff 1’s hair during the incident, but they never saw
Staff 1 pull Youth A’s hair. They all reported Youth A punched and hit staff, but no
one punched or hit Youth A.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 8/26/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported when she and Staff 1
were in the milieu, she felt Staff 1 was pulling her hair and it felt like Staff 1 pulled a
chunk of hair out, so Youth A became more upset. Youth A reported Supervisor
released Staff 1’s hand from Youth A’s hair. Youth A reported no staff hit, slapped,
or punched her during the incident.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 9/1/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported she was only present for
the incident in the hallway outside of the bedrooms. Youth B heard Youth A yelling
Staff 1 was holding onto Youth A’s hair. Youth B reported she was trying to tell
Youth A no one was holding onto her hair, but Youth A was not listening.
Nurse was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 8/26/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Nurse met with Youth A on 8/25/22 and
Youth A reported her head hurt because a chunk of her hair was pulled out during
the incident on 8/24/22. Nurse felt her head and did not feel any bumps, irritation, or
anything unordinary. Nurse checked Youth A’s head for patches of hair missing and
did not find any.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 9/1/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Director was also present. Staff 1
reported during the incident on 8/24/22, she and Staff 2 had attempted to restrain
Youth A but were unsuccessful. Staff 1 felt a pain in her side and thought Youth A
was biting her, so she pushed Youth A’s head downward. Staff 1 reported Youth A
began yelling that Staff 1 was pulling her hair, but she believes her lanyard became
tangled in Youth A’s hair. Staff 1 reported she pulled her lanyard to release it and it
might have pulled Youth A’s hair, but she was not sure. Staff 1 reported she never
intentionally pulled Youth A’s hair and did not punch, slap, or hit Youth A.
3

Video Reviewed:
Video footage of the milieu and hallway of Renucci Home for 8/24/22 was
reviewed on 8/26/22, 9/1/22 and 9/16/22. Although there were two points in the
milieu the camera view was out of range and the hallway was not clear due to the
camera angle, interviews conducted provided details on what occurred at those
times. The video did not show Staff 1 pulling Youth A’s hair and did not show Staff 1
slapped, hitting, or punching Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
 MiSACWIS Incident Reports (#140590200, 140590201 and 140590202) were
consistent with video footage reviewed as well as Supervisor and Staff 2’s
interviews.
 Critical Incident/Adverse Event Report Form completed by Staff 1 on 8/25/22.
This was consistent with Staff 1’s interview, except does not mention anything
regarding the lanyard becoming stuck in Youth A’s hair and being pulled.
 Medical Note completed by Nurse dated 8/25/22 was consistent with Nurse’s
interview.
 Staff 1’s personnel file was reviewed. Staff 1 has not had any disciplinary
actions. Staff 1 completed Aegis Initial Training on 9/29/21. She completed
Aegis Benevolent Holding Skills Residential Team meeting trainings on
9/30/21, 1/20/22 and 4/28/22. She completed Aegis: Building Empathy
training on 2/24/22. She completed Aegis Staff Empowerment Review Team
meeting trainings on 10/14/21 and 2/3/22. Staff 1 also completed Basic
Communication and Conflict Management Skills Training on 11/22/21.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow
written policies and procedures that prohibit the
following forms of intervention:
a. Any type of physical punishment including, but
not limited to:
ii. Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking,
pulling, or pushing a youth on any part of
their body.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in compliance as there is no evidence to
support any staff hit, slapped, or punched Youth A or
intentionally pulled Youth A’s hair.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
4

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
On 8/24/22, Staff 1 failed to follow the facility’s Behavior Management Policy.
INVESTIGATION:
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 8/26/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported the night of the incident
she did not want to give the computer back to staff when it was bedtime, and the 2nd
shift staff were not forcing her to give the computer back. However, when Staff 1
came in for 3rd shift, Staff 1 put her stuff down and came right over to Youth A and
told her she had to give the computer back. Youth A stated it became escalated very
quickly because Staff 1 approached her so abruptly and was very demanding. Youth
A reported Staff 1 entered Youth A’s personal space and Youth A felt Staff 1 was
immediately going to become physical with her. Youth A stated she stood up with
the computer in hand and then Supervisor and Staff 2 surrounded her on her sides.
Youth A reported when she stood up, Staff 1 said “Who do you think you are?”. Staff
1 attempted to grab the computer but failed. Youth A felt since staff were
surrounding her, they were going to put their hands on her, so she threw the
computer because she felt she had to defend herself. Youth A stated Supervisor
was trying to keep people separated, but she could not remember if Supervisor
asked Staff 1 to leave. Youth A stated Staff 1 continued to go after her instead of
walking away or leaving the home. In the hallway, Youth A reported she was
hanging onto Staff 1’s hair and called Youth B into the hallway to help her, but Youth
B ended up helping Youth A calm down instead. Once Youth A was calm, she
stopped fighting and let go of Staff 1’s hair. Youth A showed she had 3 small bruises
on the underside of the top of her right arm, a bruise on her lower right arm and two
small bruises on the underside of the top of her left arm.
Director was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 8/26/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Director reported the facility implemented a
safety plan due to the nature of the allegations, which includes Staff 1 remaining on
administrative leave pending the results of the investigation.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 8/26/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Director was also present. Staff 2
reported Youth A was not supposed to have a laptop late at night. However, he and
Supervisor developed a plan to refrain from a power struggle. Instead, they decided
to let the laptop die and not provide a power strip to charge it. Staff 2 reported Staff 1
came in for 3rd shift, did not complete a shift change check in like she was supposed
to but instead immediately approached Youth A. Staff 1 told Youth A she was not
supposed to be on the laptop, got close to Youth A and tried to take the laptop.
Youth A pushed Staff 1 and they were verbally arguing with each other. Staff 1 got
closer to Youth A, Youth A backed up, Staff 1 tried to take the computer again and
Youth A became more upset and pushed Staff 1 again. Staff 2 reported he and the
Supervisor were trying to stop the situation, but Staff 1 seemed to be taunting Youth
A to an extent. Staff 2 and Supervisor positioned themselves on either side of Youth
5

A in case things became more physical between Youth A and Staff 1. Staff 1 made a
comment about Youth A returning home and Youth A spit on Staff 1. Staff 2 stated
Youth A was continuously asking for Staff 1 to back up and give Youth A space, but
Staff 1 was not listening. Youth A began punching Staff 1, so Staff 2 attempted to
restrain Youth A for a 1:1 hold. The restraint failed because they ran into a couch, so
Staff 2 disengaged. Staff 2 reported he and Supervisor continued to try and create
space between Staff 1 and Youth A by positioning themselves in between them.
Youth A attempted to attack Staff 1 again, but the Supervisor stood in between, so
Youth A tried to punch Supervisor. Staff 2 attempted another 1:1 restraint, but Youth
A turned herself against the couch, so he disengaged. Staff 1 and Staff 2 then
attempted a Level 1 restraint, which was also not successful, so they disengaged.
Once released, Youth A threw a book and a DVD player at Staff 1. Youth A then
backed up into the dining room area and Staff 1 continued to approach Youth A.
Youth A threw a water bottle at Staff 1. Staff 1 still did not back up, so Youth A
grabbed a broom and hit Staff 1 with it. The broom broke and Youth A still had part
of the broom. Staff 1 attempted to take it from her. Youth A grabbed Staff 1’s hair
and dragged her into the hallway outside of the bedrooms. Youth B was able to calm
Youth A down, Youth A released Staff 1’s hair and the incident concluded.
Throughout the interaction, Staff 2 and Supervisor repeatedly asked Staff 1 to leave,
but Staff 1 did not respond and did not leave. Staff 2 reported in training they are
taught to de-escalate prior to going hands on, but at no point did Staff 1 utilize any
techniques to de-escalate the situation.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 9/1/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Director was also present. Staff 3 came in
for 3rd shift and Youth A was in the milieu on a laptop. Staff 3 touched base with
Staff 2 to get an update on what happened during 2nd shift as it is expected staff
conduct a debrief between shifts. Approximately 20-30 minutes later, Staff 1 came in
for 3rd shift. Staff 3 reported she works with Staff 1 often and Staff 1 did not appear
to be in an abnormal or escalated emotional state when she came in for her shift.
Staff 3 stated things were calm prior to Staff 1 abruptly approaching Youth A and
attempting to grab the laptop, which caused the situation to quickly escalate
afterwards. Staff 3 reported the same series of events noted in Staff 2’s interview.
However, Staff 3 could not remember if anyone asked Staff 1 to leave. Staff 3 stated
there were many times Staff 1 could have left, which likely would have de-escalated
the situation.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 9/1/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Director was also present. Staff 4’s
interview was consistent with Staff 2’s interview, however, Staff 4 was not present
for the interaction in the hallway. Staff 4 confirmed Supervisor and Staff 2 were
asking Staff 1 to back up and/or leave throughout the entire interaction, but Staff 1
was not listening. Staff 4 reported there were 3 doors Staff 1 could have exited from,
which were not near Youth A. Staff 4 reported Staff 1 appeared to be instigating the
situation and was trying to assert her dominance over Youth A from the beginning.
6

Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 9/1/22 in conjunction with the
MDHHS Worker. Director was also present. Supervisor’s interview was consistent
with Staff 2’s interview. Supervisor noted she was sitting behind Youth A when Staff
1 came in for her shift. Supervisor stated Staff 1 came over to Youth A and said,
“What are you doing with a computer?”. Supervisor told Staff 1 Youth A was doing
homework to which Staff 1 chuckled and inappropriately said, “Youth A doing
homework? Oh, that’s funny.” Supervisor reported when she continued to tell Staff 1
to leave the area during the incident, Staff 1 was not listening and never verbally
responded to Supervisor’s direction.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on site at the facility on 9/1/22 in
conjunction with the MDHHS Worker. Director was also present. Staff 1 stated
Youth A operates with intimidation, threats and bullying so other staff are afraid to
tell her no or hold her to the rules, but Staff 1 is not. Staff 1 reported when she came
in for her shift, she noticed Youth A on the computer in the milieu with Supervisor
sitting behind Youth A. Staff 1 stated Youth A has previously refused to give up the
laptop before bed on two occasions, so it had been decided Youth A would not get a
computer since she could not follow the rules. Staff 1 admitted when Supervisor told
her Youth A was doing homework, she chuckled. Staff 1 felt Youth A needed to give
back the laptop immediately because 2nd shift was ending soon and Staff 1 wanted
the additional staff support present because she knew it would end up in Youth A
being restrained. Staff 1 stated with Youth A, “you either leave her be or restrain her
to get her down” and in this situation it would not have worked to “leave her be”.
Staff 1 reported she attempted to physically take the computer and Youth A punched
her and spit at her. Staff 1 reported Youth A was still escalated and tried to punch
staff, so she and Staff 2 attempted to do a Level 1 restraint but did not communicate
well, so it was unsuccessful. Youth A swung a broom at Staff 1 and Staff 1 tried to
block it, which broke the broom handle. Staff 1 stated she asked for more support
since she knew she was triggering Youth A and staff were not communicating well
regarding a restraint. Staff 1 stated when she asked for additional support,
Supervisor replied by saying “More support? Why?”. Staff 1 admitted Supervisor
asked Staff 1 to leave multiple times, but commented Supervisor is “small and cute”
and felt Supervisor could not handle the escalated situation since Youth A punched
Supervisor a couple times. Staff 1 reported she finally left the house after Youth A
released her hair in the hallway after a staff member from Cebelak came over for
support.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage (including sound) of the milieu and hallway of Renucci Home for
8/24/22 was reviewed on 8/26/22, 9/1/22 and 9/16/22. Although there were two
points in the milieu where the camera view was out of range and the hallway was not
clear due to the camera angle, interviews conducted provided details on what
occurred at those times. The video was consistent with Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, and
Supervisor interviews. Staff 1 immediately approached Youth A in an aggressive
fashion as soon as Staff 1 began her shift. Throughout the video, Staff 1 repeatedly
7

approached Youth A even after Youth A told Staff 1 to back up and Staff 2 and
Supervisor were heard telling Staff 1 to leave.
Documents Reviewed:
 MiSACWIS Incident Reports (#140590200, 140590201 and 140590202) were
consistent with video footage reviewed as well as Supervisor and Staff 2’s
interviews.
 Critical Incident/Adverse Event Report Form completed by Staff 1 on 8/25/22.
This was consistent with Staff 1’s interview, however additionally Staff 1
reported “Youth A had spent the evening being belligerent and threatening
staff.” Staff 1 came in for her shift on 8/24/22 and did not debrief with staff
from 2nd shift before approaching Youth A, so she would not have known of
Youth A’s prior behavior.
 St. John’s Restrictive Interventions Procedure (rev. 8/2022). Restrictive
interventions will never be used as a form of punishment, discipline or for
convenience of staff. Restrictive Interventions are a last resort if less
restrictive techniques have been exhausted. Staff must follow Aegis System.
 St. John’s Behavior Management Policy (rev. 1/11/2022). If a youth is in
crisis, diversion and de-escalation techniques must be used. Restrictive
intervention will only be used as a last resort. The use of excessive or
inappropriate use of restrictive interventions as a form of discipline to gain
compliance or for convenience is prohibited.
 Aegis System Manual (2018). Staff are expected to always use the least
restrictive option. When approaching an escalated client, staff are to assess
personal level of escalation, level of rapport with the client and current non-
verbal presentation prior to using physical intervention.
 Supervisor’s personnel file was reviewed. Supervisor had one formal written
disciplinary action on 12/20/21 for medication passing procedure. Supervisor
completed Aegis Initial Training on 9/15/21. She completed Aegis: Building
Empathy training on 2/24/22. She completed Aegis Benevolent Holding Skills
Residential Team meeting trainings on 9/30/21, 11/11/21, 1/20/22, 4/28/22
and 9/8/22. She completed Aegis Staff Empowerment Review Team meeting
trainings on 2/3/22 and 3/24/22.
 Staff 1’s personnel file was reviewed. Staff 1 has not had any disciplinary
actions. Staff 1 completed Aegis Initial Training on 9/29/21. She completed
Aegis Benevolent Holding Skills Residential Team meeting trainings on
9/30/21, 1/20/22 and 4/28/22. She completed Aegis: Building Empathy
training on 2/24/22. She completed Aegis Staff Empowerment Review Team
meeting trainings on 10/14/21 and 2/3/22. Staff 1 also completed Basic
Communication and Conflict Management Skills Training on 11/22/21.
8

 Staff 2’s personnel file was reviewed. Staff 2 has not had any disciplinary
actions. Staff 2 completed Aegis Initial Training on 9/22/21. He completed
Aegis Benevolent Holding Skills Residential Team meeting trainings on
9/30/21, 11/11/21 and 1/20/22. He completed Aegis: Building Empathy
training on 2/24/22. He completed Aegis Staff Empowerment Review Team
meeting trainings on 10/14/21 and 2/3/22.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures that describe the institution’s behavior
management system. The policies and procedures shall be
reviewed annually and updated as needed. These shall be
available to all residents, their families, and referring
agencies.
ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1 escalated the
situation by immediately approaching Youth A when arriving on
shift, refusing to remove herself from the situation even after
being directed to do so multiple times by Supervisor, and
continuously approaching Youth A escalating the situation.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

I recommend, upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, no change be
